title: Multiplication
description:
The time factor highlights the impressives both mechanism and action of nature that allows the birth of hundreds of artichokes only through its kernel that reside in its bedding and this is in direct contact with its rash and root scalp. This mechanism has guided me throughout the research process.
In my own way, I strived to connect the two worlds of life side by side: on the one hand, nature through a unique element in which my intervention would be limited to giving new shape with a limited hand work.
Intuitively, I continued the research process by choosing "Auricularia auricula-judae": This choice led me to work on the silver threads and inlays.
During the research, I was marveled by the new material I was holding in my hands. I focused on its features: I tried to understand them and how to keep the shape, while trying to control the mushroom. Then I trained on silver wire work, pearls ..
In addition to the process, I connected the two elements to create five pieces of jeweleryâ€™s reminiscent of the meeting of the two worlds I mentioned above, the rebirth and multiplication of the jewelry themselves.

title: Kadesh Kadesh Kadesh
description:
At the basis of the kiddush cup I designed is my interpretation of Friday night meals - I see Shabbat as a social holiday, which each week disconnects us from the daily frequency and allows us to meet the other.
Around the table, different worlds collide and connect with each other. To me, this meeting is dynamic, multi-event and varies from Saturday to Saturday.As a metaphor for the encounter between different worlds, I chose planetary systems as inspiration and from that I decided to work with elements with a round profile, glass cups, and number three which is a number full of cultural signs and represents physical and mathematical stability.
Later in the process I created a large number of sketches, each sketch was based on triangular connections between the elements. With the help of a computer scientist and mathematician, I tried to build an algorithm that would guide me in creating a stable model and a large number of cups.At the end of the process I narrowed down the options, in order to keep only the necessary minimum of elements, so that each element had its own role in the stability of the cups. The Kiddush cup has three position options, marked with different colors, at the meeting points with the table.

title: Nidda
description: As part of an enamel course on menstruation in its religious context, i.e .: the woman shook. During this period she checks for signs of bleeding through a tissue called a 'witness' and often in the case of a stain she has to send this witness to the rabbi to decide if it is menstrual blood or just bleeding. The private, the intimate may at any moment become a public thing. The very act of inserting the 'witness' into our intimacy and searching for the 'stain' or rather the 'non-stain' takes the inside out.
